Description: Glazed composition flared neck of a closed vase with ovoid body and ring base. Neck made up with plaster: frieze of griffins, with single row of guilloche below; running wave above, and narrow upper register festoons of ivy? leaves tied with bows. On upper surface of lip double guilloche/braid. The main register depicts winged griffins with two horns processing in clockwise direction, (two survive, one intact) interspersed with anthemion honeysuckle device. Glaze -fine quality pale green (eau de Nil) with cream for raised decoration in main frieze. Subsidiary frieze of festoons, colouring reversed. and festoons lightly incised. Core hard brown sandy colour. Only third survives, rest restored
Curator's comments: Neck of vessel with ovoid body ref. p. 256 under Vases ferme a panse ovoide et a base annulaire: Fragments de col et d'embouchure, in Nenna and Seif el Din, La vaiselle en faience d'epoque greco-romaine, 2000. See Figs 32-35, 121 for complete examples. Fig. 11 T7.1. Complete list chap. VII, pps. 251-275. Neck and body always made separately and often found separately/disjointed. Nenna, M.-D. and M. Seif el-Din. La vaisselle en faïece d’époque gréco- romaine. Études Alexandrines 4. Cairo: IFAO.

Parallels dated to the 3rd century BC (Nenna 2013, Fig. 6.5, T7.1a, see also 7.1b and c). Nenna, M.-D. 2013. Faience vessels and objects in Nicholson, P. T. (ed.) Working in Memphis: The production of faience at Roman period Kom Helul. London: Egypt Exploration Society: 106-132.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FC.10)
